item.title: The Precedents to Trump’s Venezuela Operation
item.description: In ousting and arresting Nicolás Maduro, US President Donald Trump wants the political gains of fighting a war without actually having to fight one. Whereas fascists and imperialists know that war requires real combat, Trump seems unwilling or unable to go that far, not least because he is weak at home.

item.title: Trump’s Special Military Operation in Venezuela
item.description: The framers of the US Constitution designed a system to compel the executive to explain its actions, wagering that requiring justifications would discipline power and prevent its arbitrary exercise. President Donald Trump has called that bet – and won.

item.title: How the Stock Market Could Sink Trump in 2026
item.description: By emphasizing how well the US stock market is doing, US President Donald Trump could be setting himself up for electoral disappointment this November. With equities priced for perfection, any number of risks could deflate today's exuberance.

item.title: Trump’s Fear and Loathing of Europe
item.description: Just as some early-20th-century German nationalists viewed Russia as a useful ally against more liberal European countries and the "racially chaotic" United States, the US under Donald Trump regards Russia and Hungary as friends united against a common enemy: Europe. There are several reasons for this reversal.

item.title: The Trump Doctrine in Venezuela
item.description: The US military operation to arrest Nicolás Maduro underscores President Donald Trump’s view of the Western Hemisphere as a region where US interests take precedence. Russia and China will welcome this as a sign that Trump shares their vision of a world divided into spheres of influence.

item.title: Trump’s Travel Bans Threaten US National Security
item.description: For all Donald Trump’s talk about security, he proves far more interested in lining his own pockets. No country that hosts a major Trump-branded property or strikes a high-profile business deal with a member of Trump’s inner circle – including some with well-documented ties to global terrorism – faces US travel restrictions.

item.title: The Case for Universalism in a Fragmenting World
item.description: The current wave of hyper-nationalism reflects growing anxiety over a deeply interconnected global economy that no longer fits neatly within political borders. While a world without nation-states remains a distant dream, we can at least strengthen existing supranational organizations.

item.title: Energy Will Decide the AI Race
item.description: Although the race to dominate AI has so far focused on cutting-edge chips and capital expenditures, all the data centers in the world will not help you if they lack a continuous supply of affordable energy. While China clearly understands this, America may not, and that could create an opportunity for Europe.

item.title: The Truth About Europe’s Regulation of Digital Platforms
item.description: US President Donald Trump claims that Europeans are engaging in "censorship" when they require digital platforms to be transparent about their algorithms and to remove already illegal content. With the US recently barring entry to five Europeans it accuses of regulating online content, it is time to set the record straight.

item.title: The Post-2025 World Order
item.description: Last year will be remembered as one of global reckoning. The future of the international order remains unknown, but now we know which countries are best prepared to adapt to the loss of what came before.

item.title: Israel Unbound
item.description: While the United States and its allies finally led a push to end the Gaza war in 2025, it is not clear how regional stability will be restored, or what shape a new regional order will assume. For the foreseeable future, the Middle East will be bracing for a prolonged conflict as Israel pursues military supremacy.

item.title: Where Is the US Economy Headed in 2026?
item.description: After a tumultuous 12 months for the US economy, the coming year may well be marked by even greater upheaval. From the likelihood that President Donald Trump’s tariff chickens will come home to roost to the risk of a stock-market crash, there is good reason to fear that the global economy’s most powerful engine may stall.

item.title: The Big Picture
The Case for European Nationalism
item.description: Despite US President Donald Trump’s claims to the contrary, Europe’s problem is not too much integration but too little. To endure in a world increasingly dominated by continental powers, the European Union must complete its common institutions and forge a shared political identity capable of sustaining them.

item.title: The World Order After 2025
item.description: While the term “polycrisis” can be useful in describing the tangle of threats the world currently faces, it fails to capture our role in creating – or finding a way out of – our current situation. While profound disruption carries acute risks, it also provides a rare opening for far-reaching transformation.

item.title: Silicon Valley Socialism
item.description: Tech titans like Elon Musk are offering us a future of socialism from above, where they keep the means of production while everyone else gets an allowance. But if the allowance is high enough, should we care who owns the algorithms and data centers?

item.title: The West Is Not Ready for a Multipolar World
item.description: The world is shifting from a largely hegemonic international system to a more fragmented, contested, and multipolar set of arrangements. In this environment, the central question for the West is not how to revive a dying order, but how to operate credibly and responsibly in one where influence must be shared.

item.title: Climate Adaptation More Than Covers Its Cost
item.description: Effective climate adaptation can strengthen countries’ resilience, protect vulnerable communities, and support economic growth. But while the world has the tools, the level of investment needed to close today’s adaptation gap, let alone to address likely future needs, has fallen far short.

item.title: Against Euro-Pessimism
item.description: Over the past year, Europe has become an unseemly hybrid: a punching bag and a laughingstock. But even if recent events make it difficult to feel optimistic, the continent's history offers plenty of reminders that reinvention and recovery are the rule, not the exception.

item.title: How to Tax AI
item.description: By responding to economic insecurity with increasingly blunt tools like minimum-wage hikes, policymakers are overlooking the deeper problem: the accelerating decoupling of human labor time from economic value. The only solution is to recognize machine time as a distinct production input and price it accordingly.
